title: Senators, Wikstrand continue stalemate
text:
Time to sit and ponder his future has not changed Mikael Wikstrand's stance. 
And Bryan Murray is still not willing to budge. 
The Senators' GM said he heard from Wikstrand's camp on the weekend in the form of another request that the defenceman be permitted to stay home and play hockey in Sweden. 
Wanting the signed prospect to develop his game in North America, Murray replied no. Again. 
"Same answer," Murray told members of the media at Canadian Tire Centre Tuesday. "I got a text from Mikael yesterday afternoon. I haven't answered him yet, I will today. He would like to stay home. He can stay home but he can't play hockey, and he wants to play over there. 
"We have to take a stand here at this time. If it changes later on, it changes later on. But that's not the message I'm sending to him." 
Despite knowing the Senators' preference -- and despite saying he would be fine with playing in Binghamton -- Wikstrand bolted from Ottawa just before main camp started without informing the team of his intentions until he was at the airport. 
At the time, Murray said Wikstrand can "be a grocery clerk and play beer league hockey," but he just couldn't play hockey for money with any other team. 
Wikstrand countered by stating he didn't want to leave home because a family member was seriously ill. 
"Supposedly his brother is sick, and he'd like to be closer to home," Murray said Tuesday. "But I think the team he hopes to play for would be three hours away, and we're about eight hours away on an airplane, so I don't think there's that big a difference. 
"But I do understand, if there's an illness. I understand that part of it. The point being he made a commitment to play here, we signed him to a contract and paid him accordingly, to our obligations, and we're asking him to honour that contract at this point in time."
